goals_and_objectives.description: Make it simple to automate the application and validation of FedRAMP security requirements.
80%+ of requirements will have automated validation without the need to write a single word about how it works, compared to 100% of current controls requiring narrative explanations
Technical controls will make sense and match standard configuration choices
Simplify the compliance process through automation and standardization
Reduce manual documentation burden on cloud service providers
Enable continuous compliance monitoring and validation
Improve 3PAO assessment efficiency through automated evidence collection
Establish machine-readable compliance validation framework
Create reusable compliance automation patterns for cloud architectures
Demonstrate practical implementation of cloud-native security controls
Validate effectiveness of automated security assessment approaches
Reduce time-to-authorization through streamlined assessment processes
Prove scalability of automated compliance validation across multiple cloud systems
Establish foundation for continuous authorization model
Create industry best practices for cloud security automation
Enable real-time compliance status reporting and monitoring
Reduce compliance operational costs through automation
Improve accuracy and consistency of security assessments
Facilitate faster security control implementation and validation
Support FedRAMP modernization through innovative assessment approaches

fedramp_rules.rule_text: Cloud service providers MUST apply ALL Key Security Indicators to ALL aspects of their cloud service offering that are within the FedRAMP Minimum Assessment Scope.
All parties SHOULD follow FedRAMP's best practices and technical assistance on assessing Key Security Indicators where applicable.
(INTERIM RULE) All parties SHOULD continuously monitor and review materials in the FedRAMP 20x Phase One (20xP1) pilot requirements and the 20x Community Working Group.
fedramp_rules.notes: Temporary rule for Phase One pilot program

fedramp_rules.rule_text: Cloud service providers MUST include all components within the Minimum Assessment Scope in their FedRAMP authorization boundary.
fedramp_rules.notes: Ensures comprehensive coverage of all critical components

fedramp_rules.rule_text: All MAS components must be properly documented and assessed by the 3PAO.
fedramp_rules.notes: Requires formal 3PAO validation of all MAS components

fedramp_rules.rule_text: Automated validation tools must be properly configured and validated before use in assessments.
fedramp_rules.notes: Ensures reliability of automated assessment results

fedramp_rules.rule_text: Automated validation results must be reviewed and verified by qualified assessment personnel.
fedramp_rules.notes: Maintains quality assurance in automated assessments

fedramp_rules.rule_text: Pilot participants must provide feedback on FedRAMP 20x processes and requirements.
Pilot systems must demonstrate practical implementation of automated validation approaches.
fedramp_rules.notes: Proves viability of automated assessment methods

fedramp_rules.rule_text: All evidence must be properly collected, stored, and made available for 3PAO review.
Automated evidence collection must maintain integrity and non-repudiation.
fedramp_rules.notes: Critical for audit and compliance purposes

fedramp_rules.rule_text: Systems must implement continuous monitoring capabilities for ongoing compliance validation.
fedramp_rules.notes: Foundation for future continuous authorization model

fedramp_rules.rule_text: Continuous monitoring results must be regularly reviewed and acted upon.
Pilot participants should explore innovative approaches to cloud security assessment.
All parties must actively participate in FedRAMP 20x community collaboration and knowledge sharing.
fedramp_rules.notes: Essential for collective advancement of cloud security practices

complete_ksi_requirements.requirement_text: Configure ALL information resources to limit inbound and outbound traffic.
Design systems to minimize attack surface and lateral movement.
Use logical networking to enforce traffic flow controls.
Use immutable infrastructure with defined functionality.
Have denial of service protection.
Design systems for high availability and rapid recovery.
Ensure cloud-native information resources are implemented based on host provider's best practices.
Harden and review network and system configurations.
Encrypt or otherwise secure network traffic.
Encrypt all federal and sensitive information at rest.
Manage configuration centrally.
Enforce system and information resource integrity through cryptographic means.
Use automated key management systems to manage, protect, and regularly rotate digital keys and certificates.
Use a consistent, risk-informed approach for applying security patches.
Enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) using methods that are difficult to intercept or impersonate for all user authentication.
Use secure passwordless methods for user authentication and authorization when feasible, otherwise enforce strong passwords with MFA.
Enforce appropriately secure authentication methods for non-user accounts and services.
Use a least-privileged, role and attribute-based, and just-in-time security authorization model for all user and non-user accounts and services.
Apply zero trust design principles.
Automatically disable or otherwise secure accounts with privileged access in response to suspicious activity.
Operate a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) or similar system(s) for centralized, tamper-resistant logging of events, activities, and changes.
Regularly review and audit logs.
Rapidly detect and remediate or mitigate vulnerabilities.
Perform authenticated vulnerability scanning on information resources.
Perform Infrastructure as Code and configuration evaluation and testing.
Centrally track and prioritize the mitigation and/or remediation of identified vulnerabilities.
Log and monitor system modifications.
Execute changes through redeployment of version controlled immutable resources rather than direct modification wherever possible.
Implement automated testing and validation of changes prior to deployment.
Have a documented change management procedure.
Evaluate the risk and potential impact of any change.
Have an up-to-date information resource inventory or code defining all deployed assets, software, and services.
Have policies outlining the security objectives of all information resources.
Maintain a vulnerability disclosure program.
Build security considerations into the Software Development Lifecycle and align with CISA Secure By Design principles.
Document methods used to evaluate information resource implementations.
Have a dedicated staff and budget for security with executive support, commensurate with the size, complexity, scope, and risk of the service offering.
Document risk management decisions for software supply chain security.
Identify all third-party information resources.

Regularly confirm that services handling federal information or are likely to impact the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of federal information are FedRAMP authorized and securely configured.
Identify and prioritize mitigation of potential supply chain risks.
Monitor third party software information resources for upstream vulnerabilities, with contractual notification requirements or active monitoring services.
Ensure all employees receive security awareness training.
Require role-specific training for high risk roles, including at least roles with privileged access.
Define Recovery Time Objectives (RTO) and Recovery Point Objectives (RPO).
Develop and maintain a recovery plan that aligns with the defined recovery objectives.
Perform system backups aligned with recovery objectives.
Regularly test the capability to recover from incidents and contingencies.
Report incidents according to FedRAMP requirements and cloud service provider policies.
Maintain a log of incidents and periodically review past incidents for patterns or vulnerabilities.
Generate after action reports and regularly incorporate lessons learned into operations.
